title: Why to Start a Startup in a Bad Economy
title_zh: [待翻译] Why to Start a Startup in a Bad Economy

paragraphs: Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. October 2008The economic situation is apparently so grim that some experts fear we may be in for a stretch as bad as the mid seventies.When Microsoft and Apple were founded.As those examples suggest, a recession may not be such a bad time to start a startup.

I'm not claiming it's a particularly good time either. The truth is more boring: the state of the economy doesn't matter much either way.If we've learned one thing from funding so many startups, it's that they succeed or fail based on the qualities of the founders.

The economy has some effect, certainly, but as a predictor of success it's rounding error compared to the founders.Which means that what matters is who you are, not when you do it. If you're the right sort of person, you'll win even in a bad economy.

And if you're not, a good economy won't save you. Someone who thinks "I better not start a startup now, because the economy is so bad" is making the same mistake as the people who thought during the Bubble "all I have to do is start a startup, and I'll be rich."So if you want to improve your chances, you should think far more about who you can recruit as a cofounder than the state of the economy.

And if you're worried about threats to the survival of your company, don't look for them in the news. Look in the mirror.But for any given team of founders, would it not pay to wait till the economy is better before taking the leap?

If you're starting a restaurant, maybe, but not if you're working on technology. Technology progresses more or less independently of the stock market. So for any given idea, the payoff for acting fast in a bad economy will be higher than for waiting.

Microsoft's first product was a Basic interpreter for the Altair. That was exactly what the world needed in 1975, but if Gates and Allen had decided to wait a few years, it would have been too late.Of course, the idea you have now won't be the last you have.

There are always new ideas. But if you have a specific idea you want to act on, act now.That doesn't mean you can ignore the economy. Both customers and investors will be feeling pinched. It's not necessarily a problem if customers feel pinched: you may even be able to benefit from it, by making things that save money.

Startups often make things cheaper, so in that respect they're better positioned to prosper in a recession than big companies.Investors are more of a problem. Startups generally need to raise some amount of external funding, and investors tend to be less willing to invest in bad times.

They shouldn't be. Everyone knows you're supposed to buy when times are bad and sell when times are good. But of course what makes investing so counterintuitive is that in equity markets, good times are defined as everyone thinking it's time to buy.

You have to be a contrarian to be correct, and by definition only a minority of investors can be.So just as investors in 1999 were tripping over one another trying to buy into lousy startups, investors in 2009 will presumably be reluctant to invest even in good ones.You'll have to adapt to this.

But that's nothing new: startups always have to adapt to the whims of investors. Ask any founder in any economy if they'd describe investors as fickle, and watch the face they make. Last year you had to be prepared to explain how your startup was viral.

Next year you'll have to explain how it's recession-proof.(Those are both good things to be. The mistake investors make is not the criteria they use but that they always tend to focus on one to the exclusion of the rest.)Fortunately the way to make a startup recession-proof is to do exactly what you should do anyway: run it as cheaply as possible.

For years I've been telling founders that the surest route to success is to be the cockroaches of the corporate world. The immediate cause of death in a startup is always running out of money. So the cheaper your company is to operate, the harder it is to kill.

And fortunately it has gotten very cheap to run a startup. A recession will if anything make it cheaper still.If nuclear winter really is here, it may be safer to be a cockroach even than to keep your job.

Customers may drop off individually if they can no longer afford you, but you're not going to lose them all at once; markets don't "reduce headcount."What if you quit your job to start a startup that fails, and you can't find another?

That could be a problem if you work in sales or marketing. In those fields it can take months to find a new job in a bad economy. But hackers seem to be more liquid. Good hackers can always get some kind of job.

It might not be your dream job, but you're not going to starve.Another advantage of bad times is that there's less competition. Technology trains leave the station at regular intervals. If everyone else is cowering in a corner, you may have a whole car to yourself.You're an investor too.

As a founder, you're buying stock with work: the reason Larry and Sergey are so rich is not so much that they've done work worth tens of billions of dollars, but that they were the first investors in Google.

And like any investor you should buy when times are bad.Were you nodding in agreement, thinking "stupid investors" a few paragraphs ago when I was talking about how investors are reluctant to put money into startups in bad markets, even though that's the time they should rationally be most willing to buy?

Well, founders aren't much better. When times get bad, hackers go to grad school. And no doubt that will happen this time too. In fact, what makes the preceding paragraph true is that most readers won't believe it—at least to the extent of acting on it.So maybe a recession is a good time to start a startup.

It's hard to say whether advantages like lack of competition outweigh disadvantages like reluctant investors. But it doesn't matter much either way. It's the people that matter. And for a given set of people working on a given technology, the time to act is always now.Russian TranslationChinese TranslationJapanese Translation

paragraphs.original: Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. October 2008The economic situation is apparently so grim that some experts fear we may be in for a stretch as bad as the mid seventies.When Microsoft and Apple were founded.As those examples suggest, a recession may not be such a bad time to start a startup.
paragraphs.translated: 想创业吗？那就让Y Combinator资助你。2008年10月，经济形势看起来如此严峻，以至于一些专家担心我们可能会经历一段像上世纪七十年代中期那样糟糕的时期。当时微软和苹果公司就是在那个时期成立的。这些例子表明，经济衰退时期可能并不是创业的坏时机。

paragraphs.original: I'm not claiming it's a particularly good time either. The truth is more boring: the state of the economy doesn't matter much either way.If we've learned one thing from funding so many startups, it's that they succeed or fail based on the qualities of the founders.
paragraphs.translated: 我并不是说现在是个特别好的时期。事实上，真相更平淡无奇：经济状况如何并不太重要。如果我们从资助众多初创公司中学到了一件事，那就是它们的成功或失败主要取决于创始人的素质。

paragraphs.original: The economy has some effect, certainly, but as a predictor of success it's rounding error compared to the founders.Which means that what matters is who you are, not when you do it. If you're the right sort of person, you'll win even in a bad economy.
paragraphs.translated: 经济确实有一定影响，但与创始人相比，它对成功预测的影响微乎其微。这意味着重要的是你是谁，而不是你何时去做。如果你是合适的人，即使在经济不景气的情况下也能获胜。

paragraphs.original: And if you're not, a good economy won't save you. Someone who thinks "I better not start a startup now, because the economy is so bad" is making the same mistake as the people who thought during the Bubble "all I have to do is start a startup, and I'll be rich."So if you want to improve your chances, you should think far more about who you can recruit as a cofounder than the state of the economy.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你不是这样的人，良好的经济状况也救不了你。那些认为“现在经济这么糟糕，我最好不要开始创业”的人，犯了和互联网泡沫时期那些认为“只要开始创业，我就能发财”的人同样的错误。所以，如果你想提高成功的几率，你应该更多地考虑你能招到怎样的联合创始人，而不是经济状况。

paragraphs.original: And if you're worried about threats to the survival of your company, don't look for them in the news. Look in the mirror.But for any given team of founders, would it not pay to wait till the economy is better before taking the leap?
paragraphs.translated: 如果你担心公司生存的威胁，不要在新闻中寻找这些问题。看看镜子里的自己。但是，对于任何一组创始人来说，在经济形势好转之前，等待再迈出这一步不是更明智吗？

paragraphs.original: If you're starting a restaurant, maybe, but not if you're working on technology. Technology progresses more or less independently of the stock market. So for any given idea, the payoff for acting fast in a bad economy will be higher than for waiting.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你要开一家餐馆，可能需要考虑，但如果你是在从事技术工作，就不必如此。技术的进步在很大程度上独立于股市。因此，对于任何给定的想法，如果在经济不景气时迅速行动，其回报将高于等待。

paragraphs.original: Microsoft's first product was a Basic interpreter for the Altair. That was exactly what the world needed in 1975, but if Gates and Allen had decided to wait a few years, it would have been too late.Of course, the idea you have now won't be the last you have.
paragraphs.translated: 微软的第一个产品是为阿尔泰尓计算机开发的Basic解释器。这正是1975年世界所需要的，但如果比尔·盖茨和保罗·艾伦决定再等几年，那就太晚了。当然，你现在有的想法不会是你最后一个。

paragraphs.original: There are always new ideas. But if you have a specific idea you want to act on, act now.That doesn't mean you can ignore the economy. Both customers and investors will be feeling pinched. It's not necessarily a problem if customers feel pinched: you may even be able to benefit from it, by making things that save money.
paragraphs.translated: 总会有新的想法。但如果你有一个具体的想法想要付诸行动，那就现在行动吧。这并不意味着你可以忽视经济状况。顾客和投资者都会感到压力。顾客感到压力并不一定是坏事：你甚至可以从中受益，通过提供节省成本的产品或服务。

paragraphs.original: Startups often make things cheaper, so in that respect they're better positioned to prosper in a recession than big companies.Investors are more of a problem. Startups generally need to raise some amount of external funding, and investors tend to be less willing to invest in bad times.
paragraphs.translated: 初创企业通常能降低成本，因此在经济衰退期间，它们比大公司更有优势。然而，投资者是一个问题。初创企业通常需要筹集一定数额的外部资金，而在经济不景气时，投资者往往不太愿意投资。

paragraphs.original: They shouldn't be. Everyone knows you're supposed to buy when times are bad and sell when times are good. But of course what makes investing so counterintuitive is that in equity markets, good times are defined as everyone thinking it's time to buy.
paragraphs.translated: 他们不应该这样。每个人都知道应该在行情不好时买入，在行情好时卖出。但当然，使投资显得如此反直觉的是，在股票市场中，好时光被定义为每个人都在认为是买入的时机。

paragraphs.original: You have to be a contrarian to be correct, and by definition only a minority of investors can be.So just as investors in 1999 were tripping over one another trying to buy into lousy startups, investors in 2009 will presumably be reluctant to invest even in good ones.You'll have to adapt to this.
paragraphs.translated: 你必须有与众不同的见解才能正确，而根据定义，只有少数投资者能做到这一点。因此，就像1999年的投资者争相投资糟糕的初创公司一样，2009年的投资者可能会对即使是好的初创公司也犹豫不决。你必须适应这种情况。

paragraphs.original: But that's nothing new: startups always have to adapt to the whims of investors. Ask any founder in any economy if they'd describe investors as fickle, and watch the face they make. Last year you had to be prepared to explain how your startup was viral.
paragraphs.translated: 但这并不是什么新鲜事：初创公司总是不得不适应投资者的喜好玩意。随便问一下任何经济体中的任何创始人，如果他们认为投资者善变，看看他们的表情就知道了。去年，你必须准备好解释你的初创公司是如何具有病毒式传播性的。

paragraphs.original: Next year you'll have to explain how it's recession-proof.(Those are both good things to be. The mistake investors make is not the criteria they use but that they always tend to focus on one to the exclusion of the rest.)Fortunately the way to make a startup recession-proof is to do exactly what you should do anyway: run it as cheaply as possible.
paragraphs.translated: 明年你将不得不解释它是如何抵御经济衰退的。（这两点都是好事。投资者的错误不在于他们使用的标准，而在于他们总是倾向于只关注其中一个而忽略了其他方面。）幸运的是，使一家初创公司抵御经济衰退的方法正是你应该做的事情：尽可能地降低成本运营。

paragraphs.original: For years I've been telling founders that the surest route to success is to be the cockroaches of the corporate world. The immediate cause of death in a startup is always running out of money. So the cheaper your company is to operate, the harder it is to kill.
paragraphs.translated: 多年来，我一直在告诉创业者们，通往成功的最可靠途径就是成为企业界的蟑螂。初创企业死亡的直接原因总是资金耗尽。因此，你的公司运营成本越低，就越难被击垮。

paragraphs.original: And fortunately it has gotten very cheap to run a startup. A recession will if anything make it cheaper still.If nuclear winter really is here, it may be safer to be a cockroach even than to keep your job.
paragraphs.translated: 幸运的是，现在创办一家初创公司的成本已经变得非常低廉。经济衰退反而可能会使成本进一步降低。如果真的是核冬天来临，那么像蟑螂一样生存可能比保住工作还要安全。

paragraphs.original: Customers may drop off individually if they can no longer afford you, but you're not going to lose them all at once; markets don't "reduce headcount."What if you quit your job to start a startup that fails, and you can't find another?
paragraphs.translated: 客户可能会因为无法再负担你的服务而一个个离开，但你不会一下子失去所有客户；市场不会“裁员”。如果你辞职去创办的初创企业失败了，而且找不到另一份工作怎么办？

paragraphs.original: That could be a problem if you work in sales or marketing. In those fields it can take months to find a new job in a bad economy. But hackers seem to be more liquid. Good hackers can always get some kind of job.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你从事销售或市场营销，这可能是个问题。在经济不景气的时候，这些领域的人可能需要数月时间才能找到新工作。但黑客似乎流动性更强。优秀的黑客总能找到某种工作。

paragraphs.original: It might not be your dream job, but you're not going to starve.Another advantage of bad times is that there's less competition. Technology trains leave the station at regular intervals. If everyone else is cowering in a corner, you may have a whole car to yourself.You're an investor too.
paragraphs.translated: 这可能不是你的理想工作，但你不会饿肚子。不景气时期的另一个优势是竞争减少。技术列车定期发车。如果其他人都躲在角落里，你可能会独占一节车厢。你也是一个投资者。

paragraphs.original: As a founder, you're buying stock with work: the reason Larry and Sergey are so rich is not so much that they've done work worth tens of billions of dollars, but that they were the first investors in Google.
paragraphs.translated: 作为创始人，你是以工作换取股票：拉里和谢尔盖之所以如此富有，并不是因为他们完成了价值数百亿美元的工作，而是因为他们是谷歌的首批投资者。

paragraphs.original: And like any investor you should buy when times are bad.Were you nodding in agreement, thinking "stupid investors" a few paragraphs ago when I was talking about how investors are reluctant to put money into startups in bad markets, even though that's the time they should rationally be most willing to buy?
paragraphs.translated: 就像任何投资者一样，你应该在形势不佳时买入。几段前，当我在谈论投资者在市场不景气时不愿向初创企业投资，即使从理性上讲这应该是他们最愿意买入的时候，你是否点头同意，心里想着“愚蠢的投资者”？

paragraphs.original: Well, founders aren't much better. When times get bad, hackers go to grad school. And no doubt that will happen this time too. In fact, what makes the preceding paragraph true is that most readers won't believe it—at least to the extent of acting on it.So maybe a recession is a good time to start a startup.
paragraphs.translated: 好吧，创始人也好不到哪里去。当形势变糟时，黑客们会去读研究生。毫无疑问，这次也会如此。事实上，让前一段话成立的原因是，大多数读者不会相信它——至少不会到付诸行动的程度。所以，也许经济衰退是创办初创公司的良机。

paragraphs.original: It's hard to say whether advantages like lack of competition outweigh disadvantages like reluctant investors. But it doesn't matter much either way. It's the people that matter. And for a given set of people working on a given technology, the time to act is always now.Russian TranslationChinese TranslationJapanese Translation
paragraphs.translated: 很难说像缺乏竞争这样的优势是否能抵消像投资者犹豫不决这样的劣势。但无论如何，这并不重要。重要的是人。对于从事某项技术的一群人来说，行动的时刻永远是现在。
